content: Hi @WG-traits, meeting in 5 minutes
Notable event: sprints starts today :)
But, we don't have anything on the agenda to talk about :/
Oh right, we had an agenda we wanted to fill in during the week :sweat_smile:
https://hackmd.io/nrhN5A8sR2eY9UdfJTKcJg?both
be here in 2 minutes but I had hoped we could talk about the sprint goals and maybe advertise for a few folks :)
talking about sprint goals works
Okay, meeting time
anything notable happen in the last week?
for me, I got the builtin-copy-clone test to pass in the rustc integration (albeit with the stopgap solution)
the debruijn indices change @nikomatsakis made helps a bit
(at least, it makes it more simple in some places)
ok, I'm here now ;)
so I finished off the GoalBuilder PR
not perfect, but I think an improvement on the old code (which was pretty difficult to read)
I am going through it now
slowly

Jack Huey said:

talking about sprint goals works

in particular, didn't we have people who were asking to participate? I was thinking maybe it'd be good to collect those names and see if we can't find some tasks for them
@detrumi what's the status with the impl trait work btw?
Also @tirr-c
They seemed eager to help but seem to be on when I'm not
Didn't put much time in it last week, only rebased the PR (which uncovered one new question on the new BoundVar changes)
and @Charles Lew perhaps, who did a bit of work towards end of last sprint

detrumi said:

Didn't put much time in it last week, only rebased the PR (which uncovered one new question on the new BoundVar changes)

ok -- is that a question you wanted feedback on? :)
(is it on the PR or something?)
@Areredify did you still want to take a stab at adding the Visit trait, or did something else interest you?
https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/324/files#diff-563a3df57abd0881a3def13e3bc472c6R402
Maybe I should just be using a BoundVar with index 0, but I'm not sure
in terms of sprint goals, I added a bunch of notes to the shared type library tracking issue, and I remember thinking of some more things to add in the shower but kind of forget what they were :P
but we were also talking about adding a goal of extending the chalk book itself
I am almost finished with the Visit thing, so I am just looking for the next thing to pick up
ah, great!

Introduce Interner associated type for all vectors that appear in chalk_ir types (e.g., Vec<QuantifiedWhereClause>, Vec<ParameterKind>, etc) as well as Arc or Box

Ah, that was going to be one of my side comments on your PR @nikomatsakis lol
I am wondering about how to crisply identify those "sprint goals"
like...should we hvae a floating section in our doc that preserves them (and that we keep up to date)
or make a separate hackmd per sprint maybe?
but ina ny case, @Areredify, I can pull out and suggest some concrete tasks from rust-lang/wg-traits#16 readily enough
also I think the skill tree needs some updating, I see
Hmm, I feel like a separate doc for each sprint
and then the skill tree can tie things together
I also created some issues on the skill-tree repo itself
then, when the sprint is over or during, we can move those into the wg-traits repo
Agreed, a blank slate for the new sprint helps with prioritizing
one final thing I started doing is that I created a spreadsheet that I'm using to track the names of types in chalk/rustc
I think that filling that out is a kind of work item in and of itself
Can you allow link to view
I'm not sure you want us all to request access right now lol
and/or edit
done
I gave view
I'll give edit to specific people
I've had occasional problems with "oversharing" in the past :)
well could make it edit for now
and revert it later
that's perhaps the downside of hackmd docs
Naming changes were discussed earlier today

Jack Huey said:

that's perhaps the downside of hackmd docs

well, they have history, and their perms can be tightened
(is there a way to limit edit access on those)
We might want to spend most of a design meeting discussing that
I think it's ok
and as you said at end of sprint, we'll move to wg-traits repo
I'll make a sprint doc then..?
https://hackmd.io/kYWsWI9IS0213x0qX_1RDw
I also was thinking about naming things when reading over niko's PR
specifically around Parameter/ParameterKind/to_parameter()
let's defer the detailed bikeshedding I guess but I think a good thing for me to work on (and others) for next week is to complete that spreadsheet with more types
this also goes towards your request of trying to identify the contents of the shared type library
Niko for your work items in the wg-traits issue, do you think it's work making a specific issue on the Chalk repo for each?
and for rustc changes, how do we want to approach that

Jack Huey said:

Niko for your work items in the wg-traits issue, do you think it's work making a specific issue on the Chalk repo for each?

I did plan on doing that
and on rustc repo, as apropriate
(this wg-traits issue)
I'm moving the detailed lists out from the hackmd, I think they should live in tracking issues probably
yeah, agreed
thanks @detrumi
ok, rust-lang/wg-traits#16 is up to date -- and @Areredify I think if you wanted to pick up an item, I'd probably select one of those

I think maybe

  • Extend TypeName with variants representing scalar types (e.g., bool, u32, i32)
which I think would help @Jack Huey as well
in terms of rustc integration
that's also probably needed for builtin trait logic too
yeah it will be
so it seems like a good place to start
I can make a chalk issue for it
Another thing that I thought about: (when) do we want to start doing chalk releases?
a very good question
I'm wondering -- maybe we should consider doing on a "schedule"? it seems useful
I basically just mean "every week" or something
but maybe that's a bit silly for us
I've sort of thought that maybe once we get a "working" rustc integration (i.e. my PR is ready to merge), then we start?
we should also discuss a bit with @Florian Diebold perhaps
Yeah, right now is a bit early
I actually don't think it's too early
I don't think it's too early either; we definitely need releases to land any kind of integration
I think all the needed Chalk changes have been made to get the rustc integration PR finished/landed
But I'd probably not want to call it "1.0" yet :)
oh, definitely not
So that's something to do this sprint, then
another thought I had: with @Florian Diebold's recursive solver changes, would that be a separate crate? Or live in chalk-solve
If in a separate crate, would we want to rename chalk-engine to chalk-slg
I was wondering about that
it is not clear that the chalk-engine crate makes sense anymore
it used to be an integration point
but I think it's kind of moving to be an encapsulated impl detail
and arguably it could be brought into chalk-solve
it might be simpler if it didn't have to generic over Context etc
otoh you can tell me, @Jack Huey, if that level of genericity was helpful
Well, it makes sense in terms of abstraction
(in particular, we could introduce some similar abstraction for the recursive solver)
I think that having the chalk-engine crate being separate was extremely helpful in learning about chalk and how it works
created extend chalk TypeName with builtin types chalk#368
but, if we have essentially two different solvers, we really would need some kind of shared abstraction
ideally, yes
unless we just want to replace chalk-engine with the recursive solver when that's done
I think that's not decided yet, but ultimately we probably want to settle on one
so, @Jack Huey, should we make a tracking issue for "rustc integration MVP"?
I'm looking over the sprint hackmd and I feel like I'd like to have a tracking issue per goal
but for that, I think we need to answer 1) What are the benefits to each? 2) What are the limitations to each? 3) Is there a path to solving any of those limitations?
(at least, where it makes sense, "design meeting for const integration" probably doesn't fit that category)
Yes, a tracking issue for rustc integration MVP is good
For the design meeting goal, I made an issue of wg-traits to "track" that
(https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-traits/issues/15)
oh, ok, let's link that in
sorry, internet is being weird

Jack Huey said:

(What are the benefits to each?)

I feel like I enumerated some of that in my recursive solver write-up
I'd be happy to try to make a more "canonical" listing but maybe not at this second
(that is, we could discuss in a side topic)
sorry, that should have been a link :)
yeah, that's definitely a discussion for a side topic
And I think there's definitely "data" that can go into that decision that we don't have yet
e.g. performance, bug fixes
Anything else to discuss?
If not, we can have a quick chat about the issue @Florian Diebold brought up
I'd like to discuss the book
i.e., can we identify one or two things missing from there?
the main thing I am thinking of is
there is probalby a kind of "big picture" overview of the chalk moving parts that should be written
(this one https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/pull/331)
i.e., the role of chalk-solve etc?
hmm, I remember we had some in there
or somewhere
there is definitely material out there, andI might be misremembering how much is in the book
http://rust-lang.github.io/chalk/book/what_is_chalk/crates.html
there is also stuff in rustc-dev-guide to kind of port ove
ok, yes
I feel like there's some "block diagrmas" waiting to be added
anyway maybe there's not much to discuss
What do you mean with port over?
Like, how we do similar things in chalk?
let's say this: I feel semi-inspired to try and write some of that stuff, and I'd like feedback from folks about what is helpful/confusing :)

detrumi said:

Like, how we do similar things in chalk?

no, we used to be documenting chalk in the rustc-dev-guide
in our past effort here
ah
this new style trait solving chapter, specifically,
has a bunch of content that is still fairly relevant
I think the glossary/terminology would be super helpful to add
let's maker a little bullet list in the sprint hackmd
just earlier @Jane Lusby was asking about what ?0 means
(I added the goal at the end for the book btw)
(you see it)
And I know for a long time, I got confused as to what the difference between a bound var, an inference var, and a placeholder are
And, more so, when you use one or the other, what they mean
OK, seems good
we can add more later, but that's a great start
if you want to talk more about @Florian Diebold's Pr, maybe we should do that
the other thing I think we could do is try to pick next 'design meeting' topic
I have a few thoughts about candidates
(if we wanted to dig a bit deeper into one particular thing)
Let's pick design meeting topic first
or discuss at least
then if we have time, get to @Florian Diebold's PR
the const design meeting, when do want to have that
created move remaining vectors, boxes in chalk-ir into associated types on Interner chalk#369 btw, which I think would be another good work item for @tirr-c or @Charles Lew

Jack Huey said:

the const design meeting, when do want to have that

that was one topic, the other was talking about the "implied bounds" setup that chalk has, well-formedness, and all of that
which was coming up in the rustc integration
there's some "homework reading" for that one (implied bounds)
can you explain implied bounds?
I wonder if we could convince @scalexm to attend even :)
It may or may not mean what I think it means

Jack Huey said:

can you explain implied bounds?

there was RFC 2089, which introduces the goal
rustc already has a notion of "implied bounds", but this would be expanding on that--
today in rustc if you have trait Eq: PartialEq, say
and then you say fn foo<T: Eq>(..), you also get to assume T: PartialEq
so we expand "supertraits"
but we have other implied bounds
for example if you do fn foo<'a, T>(x: &'a T) { .. },
then inside the body of foo, we have an "implied bound" that T: 'a --
this is derived from the fact that the type &'a T is only "well-formed" if T: 'a
Is this chapter on implied bounds still up-to-date? Or does that explain the thing we're expanding on?
it's still up to date afaik
except that @scalexm and I had some conversations after that, and discussed e.g. changes to terminology
but I've also been wondering about whether we can adjust the rules so that they match rustc more closely and approach implied bounds more as a "feature flag" sort of thing
okay, so I am thinking about the same thing
how does Chalk do it?
I also encountered a problem in the old formulation with my debruijn index PR that I don't quite know how to solve (have to think it over, re-read the old design docs)
well, that chapter I think is a pretty decent explanation, but in short
we have these FromEnv rules
oh, this is new-style
so e.g. if you have fn foo<T: Eq>(..) { .. }, we will add FromEnv(T: Eq) in the "environment"
and then we have two other things
first, we have a rule Implemented(T: Eq) :- FromEnv(T: Eq) --
i.e., if you know that T: Eq from the environment, then you know that you can consider it implemented (Because your caller must have proved it)
and we have a rule like FromEnv(T: PartialEq) :- FromEnv(T: Eq), derived from the trait declaration
i.e., if the environment tells you that T: Eq, then it also tells you that T: PartialEq
put those together, and you get that if your where clause says T: Eq, you also know T: PartialEq
there are a lot of reasons that led us to this particular design that I would have to go refresh my memory on
(many of which are hopefully covered in that write-up :)

nikomatsakis said:

and we have a rule like FromEq(T: PartialEq) :- FromEnv(T: Eq), derived from the trait declaration

Should be FromEnv(T: PartialEq) :- FromEnv(T: Eq)
in any case, that basic structure is.. fine. The main difference between rustc's current behavior and chalk
Ok, this all makes sense to me
are these FromEnv(..) :- FromEnv(..) rules -- how many you create
chalk makes more, so as to enable more implications
(so we could potentially turn those off, or make it a kind of "feature flag" that controls how many you get)
Right, this is quite natural in chalk, while this was probably annoying to do in the old-style trait solving
Do you have a use-case in mind for turning them off? Debugging mainly?
This sounds like it's going to go longer than 4 minutes
3 minutes
As far as turning them off, we probably want to match rustc's behavior to start
Oh, right
ok so
I didnt' really mean to go this much in depth
but it seems good anyway
the main question is -- what should we talk about and when
yeah, it's good
right back to that
I think it'd be good to plan to discuss both const generics + implied bounds, I don't have a strong opinion about in which order
but i would like some time to prepare
Maybe let's do one next week, skip one week (i.e. talk about something different), then have the other the week after
let's maybe start with const generics?
ok, sounds good
since that seems more like a "we need to figure this out" thing, where implied bounds is more "let's match rustc"
what is the extent of the current sprint?
what is the end date, I mean?
6 weeks?
I think that means May 5?
yeah, why not
No, May 12
May 12
ok so April 7, const generics, April 21, implied bounds?
Works for me!
Wow, it's almost like we're getting organized
almost
ack!
I gotta go!
didn't realize it was 5 after :)
thanks all, this was great :)
Created https://github.com/rust-lang/wg-traits/issues/17
